limit_toast.title: {{tab}} Limit Reached
limit_toast.desc: Reduce below {{limit}} to unlock new Kana

confirm_sheet.title: Mistake Blitz
confirm_sheet.desc_1: This is an efficient way to review.
confirm_sheet.desc_3: will remove them from the list.

help_sheet.title: Instructions
help_sheet.mechanism_text:
Mistakes are removed after 2 consecutive sessions.
This prevents guessing and ensures true mastery.
help_sheet.legend_review_desc: The number in the red circle shows total mistakes.
help_sheet.legend_remove_desc: A green ring indicates 1 successful review.
help_sheet.func_blitz_desc: Start a focused test on all mistakes in the list.
help_sheet.func_sound_desc: Tap any row in the list to play audio.

settings.clear_dialog_message: Are you sure you want to delete all learning progress? This cannot be undone.
settings.clear_mistakes_message: All mastery progress (mistake history, like weak status) will be permanently reset to 'New'. This cannot be undone.

onboarding.step2_desc: Do you have a background in Chinese characters (Hanzi / Kanji / Hanja / Chá»¯ HÃ¡n)?
onboarding.option_kanji_desc: Use them as a powerful shortcut to learn Kana faster.
onboarding.option_kana_desc: Focus purely on Kana for a clean, distraction-free start.

notes.hhe: Note: Pronounced "he" in words, but "e" when used as a direction particle.
notes.hha: Note: Pronounced "ha" in words, but "wa" when used as a subject particle.
notes.hwo: Note: This is an object marker particle and is rarely used in common words.
notes.hdi: Note: ã¢ sounds the same as ã˜ (ji). Most words use ã˜ instead.
notes.hdu: Note: ã¥ sounds the same as ãš (zu). Most words use ãš instead.
notes.kdi: Note: ãƒ‚ sounds the same as ã‚¸ (ji). Most words use ã‚¸ instead.
notes.kdu: Note: ãƒ… sounds the same as ã‚º (zu). Most words use ã‚º instead.

wordNotes.hSokuon: Note: "ã£" is a sokuon (geminate consonant), doubling the next consonant sound.
wordNotes.hLongVowel: Note: "ã†" here represents a long vowel, extending the "o" sound by one beat.
wordNotes.kSokuon: Note: "ãƒƒ" is a sokuon (geminate consonant), creating a brief pause before the next consonant.
wordNotes.kLongVowel: Note: "ãƒ¼" is a long vowel mark in katakana, extending the previous vowel by one beat.

sub.good: High accuracy, keep up the momentum.
sub.pass: Not bad. Review the mistakes and try again.
sub.fail: Don't give up. Practice makes perfect.

lvl1.title: Basic Numbers
lvl1.goal_desc: <highlight>Build an intuitive ear for numbers 0-10.</highlight> This foundation is essential for mastering dates, time, and currency.
lvl1.keypoint_desc:
Focus on 'Main' readings:
Numbers 0, 4, 7, and 9 have multiple readings. Prioritize those marked with the Main badge for everyday use.

Recommended Path:
Start in "Learn Mode" to familiarize yourself with the sounds, then test your reflexes in "Challenge Mode".

lvl2.title: Tens Structure
lvl2.desc: No new words. Test your reaction speed on number combinations.

lvl3.label: 100s
lvl3.title: The Hundreds
lvl3.goal_desc: Master the special sound changes in the hundreds. Combine this with previous basics to unlock any three-digit number (e.g., 365, 890).
lvl3.keypoint_desc:
Regular Rule:
Number + hyaku (e.g., 200 ni-hyaku).

Three Key Exceptions:
300: h â†’ b â†’ byaku
600, 800: h â†’ p (+ pause) â†’ ppyaku

Note:
100 is simply hyaku. Do not add ichi.

lvl4.label: 1000s
lvl4.title: The Thousands
lvl4.goal_desc: Master the sound changes in the thousands. Combine this with previous basics to unlock any four-digit number (e.g., 1980, 2024).
lvl4.keypoint_desc:
Regular Rule:
Number + sen (e.g., 2000 ni-sen).

Two Key Exceptions:
3000: s â†’ z â†’ zen
8000: Add pause (small tsu) â†’ hassen

Note:
1000 is simply sen. Do not add ichi.

day.rune_desc: Days 1â€“10 and day 20 use unique readings from ancient Japanese. They cannot be derived from number rules and must be memorized as whole words.
day.mutant_desc: When the digit "4" appears, it mutates to ã‚ˆã£ã‹ (yokka). Affects days 4, 14, and 24.
day.trap_desc: Digit "7" must always be read as ã—ã¡ (shichi); digit "9" must always be ã (ku). Neither ãªãª nor ãã‚…ã† is accepted.
day.regular_desc: Follows the normal [number + ã«ã¡] pattern. e.g., day 11 â†’ ã˜ã‚…ã†ã„ã¡ã«ã¡.
day.tip_desc: Rune days (1â€“10) are the most frequently used dates in daily Japanese â€” prioritize them. For the other three types, understanding the rule is enough.

month.traps_desc: Three months have fixed readings that differ from everyday number pronunciation:
month.trap_7_rule: "7" must be ã—ã¡ â€” not ãªãª
month.trap_9_rule: "9" must be ã â€” not ãã‚…ã†
month.classical_desc: Each month has a traditional poetic name (e.g., January = ç¦æœˆ Mutsuki) used in greeting cards, literature, and seasonal content. Rare in everyday speech.

holiday.type_national_desc: 16 legally defined public holidays per year. Schools, banks, and most businesses are closed.
holiday.type_substitute_desc: When a national holiday falls on Sunday, the following Monday automatically becomes a holiday.
holiday.type_citizen_desc: A weekday sandwiched between two public holidays also becomes a holiday. Rare â€” occurs roughly every few years.
holiday.cat_national_desc: Legally mandated days off. Marked on calendars in red.
holiday.cat_traditional_desc: Seasonal customs and folk events (Tanabata, Obon, Setsubunâ€¦). Culturally significant but usually not days off.
holiday.cat_global_desc: Universally celebrated events adopted by Japan (Christmas, Halloween, Valentine's Dayâ€¦). Commercial holidays â€” not days off.

Scroll Drums:
Scroll to find the number you want to learn.

Double-Tap Jump:
Double-tap to quickly jump to special pronunciation times.

period.shinnya: Formal; common in weather forecasts and news
period.mimei: More formal than æ·±å¤œ; the darkest period before dawn
period.yoake: Noun form of å¤œãŒæ˜ã‘ã‚‹; when night gives way to light
period.souchou: Earlier and more formal than æœ
period.asa: The most everyday word for morning
period.gozen: Spans midnight to noon, not just morning
period.shougo: Exactly noon at 12:00, not a general midday
period.yuugata: Specifically dusk and evening, not afternoon
period.yoru: The most everyday word for night, after 19:00
period.mayonaka: Colloquial midnight; more emotive than æ·±å¤œ
